title: Move Zero Values
problem_statement:
Move Zero Values

An array arr of type int is given as an argument of solution function.

Write a program that returns an array of type int, where all zero values in arr are moved to the end of the array while preserving the order of non-zero values.

Try to implement the program as fast as possible, so that reduces the amount of calculation even when len(arr) becomes large.

Constraints

  • 0 ≤ len(arr) ≤ 10000
  • 0 ≤ arr[i] ≤ 10³

Examples

Example 1:

Input: arr = [0,1,2,3]
Output: [1,2,3,0]

Description: We need to move the '0' to the end and keep the order of the nonzero values '1,2,3'

Example 2:

Input: arr = [4,1,0,0,5]
Output: [4,1,5,0,0]

Description: We need to move the two existing zeros to the end and keep the order of nonzero values

title: Simulation of card movement on a 2D grid
problem_statement:
Simulation of card movement on a 2D grid

Given an application that organizes information by arranging cards with notes on them into lists on a two-dimensional grid. These notes can be moved across multiple lists.

Examples include billboard-based task management applications such as Trello or Jira.

Input Format

The function takes three arguments:

  1. cards: A two-dimensional array representing the initial position of cards: [CardID, RowIndex, ColumnIndex]

    Row and column indexes are zero-based.

  2. moves: A two-dimensional array representing card movements: [CardID, Row index before move, Column index before move, Destination row index, Destination column index]

    All indexes are zero-based and assumed valid.

  3. query: An integer representing the ID of the card to track.

Output Format

Return an array [row index, column index] representing the final position of the queried card.

Movement Rules

  • When a card is moved and there is a card at the destination, the existing card is moved down one row.
  • When a card is moved, other cards in the original column move up one position.
  • Cards can be moved to the same row and column as before.
  • There shall be no gaps in the initial placement.
  • We can assume that the coordinates before a move is correct.

Examples

Example 1

Input: cards=[[1,1,0], [3,0,0], [6,0,1], [4,0,2], [5,2,0], [7,1,1], [2,1,2]], query=2
Output: [2,0]

This is a case where the target moves.

Example 2

Input: cards=[[1,1,0], [3,0,0], [6,0,1], [4,0,2], [5,2,0], [7,1,1], [2,1,2]], moves=[[6,0,1,2,0], [7,0,1,0,2]], query=2
Output: [2,2]

This is a case where a card is moved to the same column as the target.

Example 3

Input: cards=[[1,1,0], [3,0,0], [6,0,1], [4,0,2], [5,2,0], [7,1,1], [2,1,2]], moves=[[6,0,1,3,0], [7,0,1,0,2]], query=5
Output: [2,0]

This is a case where the card moves to the same column as the target, but the target does not move because it is placed below.

Constraints

  • 0 <= len(cards) <= 10^5
  • 0 <= len(moves) <= 10^5
